content: There is a stream for Covid-19 Response here: https://chat.fhir.org/#narrow/stream/226195-Covid-19-Response. The related blog for related persistent documentation and links can be found here: https://confluence.hl7.org/pages/viewrecentblogposts.action?key=CR
Thank you! Is the blog limited? The Blue Ellipsis does not show, nor is there a blog yet, so wanted to make sure I see the right page.
Apologies Hans. You should be seeing correct now. Just had to index. You should be logged in to create the blog.

If you're doing something in healthcare IT to respond to Covid-19 - feel free to add it as a comment here: http://www.healthintersections.com.au/?p=3012

But if you are - and you don't have time - don't feel bad: go and save the world. Whatever you are doing is way more important
I'm looking for a volunteer that knows Swift to take on keeping this up to date:
both with regard to swift, and with regard to FHIR questionnaires
I think there's plenty of projects that would use it

@Grahame Grieve Hi , may be i can help, i know a little bit of Flutter, i made an app for my province Jujuy here in Argentina. But google its taking a long time to aprove it, send me a messeage if i am use ful for your team. Sorry about my english
I think it's in swift, not flutter... but you can have a look at it...
I'll circle it around internally ... We do have some swift guys around

@Grahame Grieve I did some work a year ago to extract the questionnaire component from this framework and update it to R4, plus fix some issues with value sets for choice responses. I need a few days work to complete the refactoring and updating, planned as a new Swift Package Manager (SPM) package for QuestionnaireKit. PM me if you have examples with specific requirements. I did not include other aspects of the C3-PRO framework, only Questionnaire rendering and QR results. Full credit to the original developer from Boston Children's, of course!!!
is your work going to be open source?

Yes, absolutely, as it's primarily based on the C3-PRO framework. So same license, same attribution to Boston Children's author. Just delayed releasing it until I clean up the extract/refactor of questionnaire support.
